Authors:
Aurelien Miralles, Jörn Köhler, David R. Vieites, Frank
Glaw, Miguel Vences
Title:
A molecular phylogeny and new species of the genus
Paracontias (Scincidae) lead to insights into rostral shield evolution
in head-first digging squamates
Keywords:
Burrowing lifestyle, Paracontias vermisaurus sp. n.,
Madagascar, scalation, Scincidae, phylogeny.
Abstract:
The rostral shield is a remarkable integumentary structure
of squamates that evolved in lizards several times independently in
different lineages of limbless skinks, and in the family Dibamidae. This
large, smooth and conical plate entirely covering the snout constitutes
one of the most derived case of reduction of the number of scales in the
rostral region, an evolutionary trend clearly associated to the
burrowing lifestyle. Here we performed a multilocus phylogenetic
analysis of combined mitochondrial and nuclear DNA of the fossorial
genus Paracontias, including a new species described herein, and
assembled a qualitative morphological study of the cephalic scalation
within this genus. Our analyses allowed us to investigate the evolution
of “fusion” of the scales of the snout into a single large rostral
shield. We discuss the evolutionary process that may have operated, and
hypothesize some of the adaptative advantages such a structure may
provide in terms of functional morphology.
